@vylc I think these changes make a lot of sense and touch on some aspects of SIP-15 regarding explicit callout. A few comments/thoughts: 

1. It's also worth pointing out that the current relative timestamp sometimes uses _now_ and other times uses _today_ as the reference point which is somewhat confusing.

2. Related to SIP-15 should we align on supporting dates and timestamps or just make everything timestamps? I proposed the former in SIP-15 but I'm not opposed to the later. Note there are other temporal grains; week, month, quarter, year etc. however we (and other BI tools) normally just encode these as dates (or timestamps), i.e., `2019-01` or `2019-Q1` is defined as `2019-01-01`.

3. For `DAY` I'm not sure that  "Today so far (now)" should reference now as we're talking about dates and not times. I'm uncertain whether it should be `[, today)` (exclusive of today) or `[, tomorrow)` (inclusive of today). 

4. We need to ensure that the time window is apparent when the widget is closed.

5. From a UX perspective we're really specifying a time window either as: i) a start and and end, ii) a start with a duration, or iii) and end with a duration, and was wondering whether there was merit in trying to design/encode this into the widget somehow (which ties into #4).  

6. We also have a time grain selector and wonder if it make sense to keep these decoupled or somehow combine them. I guess you could have a monthly time grain but the time filter is based on years (as opposed to months).
Also [here](https://docs.looker.com/reference/filter-expressions) is Looker's various date/time filters which provide some additional context regarding the various patterns they support.

I really like this proposal, as I often find myself needing an interval that isn't available. I recently opened a PR which solves a subset of this problem, namely the now/today one ( #7525 ), but I do feel that Superset would benefit a lot from adding more functionality in this space. I would like to add that `Last Month` or similar might mean very different things to different people; for one it means a moving window(e.g. `2019-04-30` to `2019-05-29`) , while for others it usually means last full period (`2019-05-01` to `Today`). This is often tightly coupled with time grains, and probably benefits from anecdotal analysis where the current functionality was insufficient.

Set the threshold to 0% based on @DiggidyDave's suggestion and removed ignore directory. Anyone have any final comments? Once we get this in I'll need to get the repo to add this as a commit check. Until then it won't change anything. Seems good to just get it in and then we can adjust as necessary.

Thanks for sharing this proposal! In the future when proposing a change to UX of the tool please add the label [design-review](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/labels/design-review). 

1. The number of defaults under for example the Default - Today tab is overwhelming. We should draw a thoughtful line around how many options we provide users. The more choices a user is presented with, the longer the user will take to reach a decision. Check out [Hick's Law](https://lawsofux.com/hicks-law).
2. This feels like a move towards supporting power user needs over general usability. It should be noted this provides greater friction for the non-power user. Having to select Today, Day, Week of Month first to find a specific default is not as user friendly/discoverable as it exists today. I question if some aspects of this should this live behind a more advanced option and/or feature flag for the time filter?
3. I appreciate that you're trying to provide greater clarity of the selected time range for the user. The placement of the what I would suggest calling "Selected Time Range" looks like a bit of an afterthought right now. My guess is this a limitation of the tool you're using to mock this up in. It would be worth thinking about the hierarchy of information here. Rank it and order it as such. I would probably place the selected time range first. I think this is a great add all around.
4. Week Start Day under Defaults > Week/Month is a bit hidden and unless I'm mistaken should probably be closer to the Today, Day, Week, Month selector.

• I like that we explicitly note the time range selected. The placement feels a little weird though; would like a design pass. Agreed with @john-bodley's point above that we should show this after selection as well. 
• I’m not sure about the [Today, day, week, month, year] drop-down in the defaults. It took me a while to grock, and I wondered at the number of defaults (could it lead to the paradox of choice?). It feels sufficiently complex that it feels like more than “Defaults” i.e. starts feeling "Custom." I think it's worth re-considering how we group these options at the highest level (relative / absolute seem like bigger distinctions, possibly).
• I like all the changes to custom tab
• I may be missing something, but I don’t think this actually solves the “Ability to adjust start time.” We could do that by adding a custom for the start date

In the production environment, there are many slices and dashboards, which serve different departments and different groups of a company. These dashboards and slices have different permission controls. For example, some dashboards are public and can be stored in public areas; some dashboards are privately owned by the department, stored in the department directory; some may be personally private, stored in a personal private directory.

This is just a practice in my company. Different companies do not necessarily have the same transformation. In short, this should be more user-friendly while meeting the data visualization needs of the company.
